user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (const char *const str1,
                               const char *const str2,
                               size_t len)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)
  {
    const char c1 = str1[i];
    const char c2 = str2[i];
    if (charsequalcaseless (c1, c2))
      continue;
    else
      return 0;
  }
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
                               const char *const str2,
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — the fragment only declares the parameter as const char *const str2 and does not call any <string.h> functions. Rule 21.17 concerns the use of functions from <string.h>, so this declaration by itself does not violate the rule. (Note: the function body performs indexed reads str1[i]/str2[i]; if callers pass buffers shorter than len an out‑of‑bounds read would occur, but that is a general buffer-overrun issue rather than a direct violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 which targets use of <string.h> functions.)
